description.text:
A Tarantula logo to attach to the top beam.

Inspired by CheopisIV from the RepRap forum : http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?406,637668

It comes in two parts : the frame, which is intented to be printed with black filament, and secured with 2 M4 grub screws, and the colored insert, to match your own colour scheme.

As it's quite tight in the profile, screws are not mendatory, and allen screws could actually be used just for the look.

Provision could be made for some internal led lighting for further bling factor.

One could also choose to only print a colored frame, and no insert,resulting in a black Tarantula logo.

The FINAL version is a 4mm thick one, with short pegs so it sits close to the 2020 profile.
The 8mm version is stil available as well as the SLIM 4mm. They sits 2mm away from the beam.

A prototype has been printed, with the T nuts on the bed and supports rather than upside-down.

The insert requires to be sligthly bent to be included in the frame, then the whole thing has to be slid from a side to the center of the top beam.

Enjoy !

this fan redirect system is a review on an existing project, my add is the channel that brings air also to the pipe before the the extruding chamber,in order to mantain it fresher and avoid filament melting in the channel. i also moved and re-designed the channel near the noozle and divide the two conducts with an asymmetric geometry in order to have more air to the noozle.

print_settings.Notes:: Careful sanding of the form removes more of the layer structure and makes it fit even more tightly in the sand.

title: Super Heavy Metal Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For this spinner, you need to cast metal in a sand mold.

Please note that using lead is problematic, as it is toxic (especially the fumes when melting it). Maybe tin would make a better choice.

The reusable form is supplied with a small handle, it is prepared to make an open mold.
Afterward, some sanding will equalize the difference in weight, so it runs smoothly.

The supplied cap is quite concave; it has to be printed upside down with some support material. But you can, of course, use any other cap for the 608 ball bearing.

I achieved 5 minutes and 13 second spinning time (speed up by hand, no compressed air or such).

Printer:

Modified Vellemann K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The cap and the form use 0.1mm layers, the body needs only 0.2mm layer height.

The cap and the form should be printed with support. The cap has its concave part (the side touching the finger) pointing upwards. The form has the part pointing towards the center of the spinner oriented to the printing bed, so the layer structure is vertical when taking the form out of the sand mold. If the form would be printed on its flat side, the mold might be spoiled.

Careful sanding of the form removes more of the layer structure and makes it fit even more tightly in the sand.

comments.text: Use zinc.  It's melting point is just a touch higher than lead, almost as heavy and it's a lot cheaper and easier to find than tin.  A lot of car wheel balancing weights are zinc these days, marked Zn or Z right on the weight.   Stop by any tire shop and ask them for a hand full of used weights.
comments.author: BolivarS

comments.text: It should be said that lead is highly toxic! Children should NOT be exposed to lead and can be poisoned!! Maybe you should rewrite your description.
comments.author: Wolfiest

comments.text: You are right with lead being toxic. In fact I did a lot of precaution to not poison my son. But for smaller children it might be difficult to explain why I do not let them play with the resulting spinner. And having everything precaution described here will be too much.
comments.author: Wolfiest

comments.text: So why suggest lead? You realise lead is toxic in solid form also? If the resulting spinner is put into the mouth, it will poison (maybe over time, but still). Not a project for children, not something a child (or even an adult) should be exposed to.
comments.author: cosudor

comments.text: I do not suggest lead. I changed the description like you suggested. My only mention of lead is saying it would be problematic. So I do not really understand your last criticism.
comments.author: Wolfiest

comments.text: I posted in reply to your last message was all - and I mentioned lead is toxic as a solid also. However, you have altered your description and you do point out that lead is toxic. I don't want to make enemies, I'm just a concerned parent. I just thought this needed pointing out for users who may not be aware. Thanks for promptly taking action.

title: Thermo dual customizable electrophoresis gel comb

description.text:
DNA gel electrophoresis comb designer for Thermo Fisher Owl system.
For each side of the comb, the number of teeth, teeth spacing, and teeth thickness is customizable in the MakerBot Customizer app. Tooth width is calculated based on number of teeth, gap distance between teeth, and comb width minus margins.
Typical tooth thicknesses are 0.75–1.5 mm.

The .scad file was modified from anoved's thing:352873 to allow separate customization of either side of the comb for the parameters above, except tooth length.

title: Wire Holder for Prusa I3 MK2S

description.text:
Since I built my Original Prusa I3 MK2S, the cables from the extruder have been working their way loose from where they enter the Rambo box. No matter how many times I secured them, the cable wrap would slip it's way up and I could see that the cloth covered wires were showing some wear. The single wire tie was insufficient.
This object will add more wire ties holding the wire wrap. So far it's working great, the cable wrap no longer works it's way out.
Print upright as designed. Turn it upside down when you install it. Needs 3 small wire ties.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20 Layer

comments.text: Thanks for this! I see now that the insulation around the thick bed heater wires on my MK2s is slowly wearing away just as you describe. This is a simple and elegant solution to improve strain relief.

author: tjcolejr

description.text:
This is a shell for encapsulating a 3/8â€ rod with BBâ€™s to act as a linear bearing. The use of NYLON makes it possible for the bearings to provide both support and a smooth rolling movement across the rod.
This part is made possible by the 2BEIGH3 3D Printer as outlined at:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Combination-CNC-Machine-and-3D-Printer/

The stl file is for discussion purposes only as it is configured for a NYLON cooling gradient as printed on a 2BEIGH3. While initial builds of the part were successful, the BBâ€™s eventually became problematic. It was discovered that not all BBâ€™s are as spherical as they appear. For best operation, and to keep cost down, the BBâ€™s were washed and then sent through a centrifugal sort.
As seen in the photo, there are some remnant threads in that retraction was not used. As the material is NYLON, they are not affected by acetone. The part was rotated in CAD such as the threads would not be in the raceways after being processed by slic3r.
Each unit uses 20+ BBâ€™s and because the part is made from NYLON, no lubrication is used or needed.
The print nozzle for these parts was a .5mm. The course nozzle was responsible for a few BBâ€™s (2%) that did not make proper contact with the rod.
The part is designed for a fluid mixing system that will automatically test water samples from various wildlife sources. pH, ORP, TDS, chlorine and certain industrial residues will be measured and documented. NYLON is the material of choice as itâ€™s not subject to chemical degradation by most of the test reagents. NYLON also requires no lubrication that can contaminate the test samples. For this part a common type of NYLON was used and for over-all rigidity, the fill was increased to 65%.
The part may be referred to as a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4718

OpenForge

Dungeon corner tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
The smooth set can be used for any number of things. Look at the Smooth floor tile set for ideas. There, I've done concrete, ice and dirt. Here I've done concrete.

OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles

  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.

  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.

  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.

title: The Clarm - Fully Modular Helping Hand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
My goal with this project was to make a set of helping hands while soldering that can be fully 3d-printed and modular.
The result became "The Clarm"

Clarm doesn't require any parts that can't be 3d-printed, no supports, just press print and you're done. You might want to print all the parts in two sessions though.
Some parts have quite a small area touching the build plate, this can become a problem for some printers. In that case you might want to add a raft to those parts.

Clarm is made up of a couple of joints and spacers, apart from the base and the claw. Just add as many joints and spacers you want for your Clarm. If you're not sure how to configure your Clarm you can pick the stl-files labeled "clarm_base_configuration_print1" and "clarm_base_configuration_print2".

| 4X | inner_thread_to_inner_ball
| 4X | outer_ball_to_inner_ball
| 4X | ball_tightener
| 1X | Evetything else

I intend to add additional claws and useful stuff that can be attached. This is a WIP and I would very much appreciate your feedback and suggestions.
And if you print this, please do a make of it and let me know how it turned out =)

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Infill:

100% threaded parts, <20% for base and larger parts

description.text: This is a configurable Mobius strip. You can control the radius, width and thickness and also the number of half-twists and initial angle. The lampshade shape has zero half-twists and an initial angle of 45. The dual mobius is two mobius strips, one with initial-angle 90. The wavy -edged strip uses a function of width and i to modulate the width with a sinusoidal function The large mobius has the width = 3 * radius. This construction uses union() which is slow and a better approach is to make use of the concat() function in the development release of Openscad to construct a polyhedron. Code is on Github https://github.com/KitWallace/openscad/blob/master/mobius_concat.scad and some discussion in http://kitwallace.tumblr.com/post/75264490978/mobius-strip mobius_2.stl was generated from that script.

Simple hanger for kitchen or other uses.
It is small - only 10 cm wide, but you can scale as you need. If you need to design part in stl, send me email to [email protected] I am not making organic shapes like statues, animals etc. I can make various holders, brackets, boxes and other technical stuff.
Made in SketchUp, skp file included.

I create a series of prefabricated 3D printed constructors. Currently, three ready-made designers are ready. In this article I will talk about the national team gun. The purpose of the project is the development of 3D printing for educational purposes.

The printing material is white PLA. The reason for choosing the material is simple:

  • low shrinkage. And since the elements of the designer should be approached to each other without fitting, shrinkage is the most important factor.
  • Excellent adhesion. Since the cannon itself is printed standing upright, a good adhesion of a small area is extremely important. However, you can still print only with the raft.
  • Safe.

The advantage of printed constructs is obvious.

  • Low cost price
  • you can select the desired scale
  • a fascinating process of printing and assembling the designer.

The cannon consists of eight parts. You can collect both on glue and without it. To paint details (if there is a desire) it is desirable still in the disassembled kind.

title: Anet A8 2017 version X cable chain with fine tune adjustment

description.text:
I completely started from scratch on this design. I even remolded the chain links in Fusion 360. Since the chain links were remodeled they print cleaner, snap together easily, and connect to the mounts perfectly. Do not mix other chain links with this use my design.

The X motor is higher so the chain doesn’t get in the way of the filament or extruder knob. I made sure it clears the tower so it won't reduce build area height. This X mount fully covers the x motor mount for the Anet A8 2017 version. Also added an access hole for installing the fine adjustment screw. I made sure the chain tracks perfectly and stays in alignment with the x mount and extruder mount which was an issue for using another versions.

You should be able to use the originals screw to mount for the X mount. I went for M3x25 with an M3 nut on the back for a spacer. I think I needed more screw bite since my motor threads started to wear a little from constantly removal during prototyping.

Fine tune adjustment screw use M3x18-25 whatever fits your setup. I'm using an M3x25 and could have gone shorter.

When mounting the endstop to the holder I drilled the 2m holes to accept 3mm screws since I have more of them laying around.

I've included a short distance adjustment knob you may want to print both and use whatever fits better. They're quick prints.

Supports are needed when to you print the X mount and end-stop mount because of the obvious overhangs.

Print 28 x chain links
Print as thumbs are shown.

description.text:
The interroll omniwheel is the cheapest set of 48mm omniwheels that you can buy here where I live. You pay 25 Eur + 5 Eur for shipping for a set of 10 (=5 wheels) in ebay whereas a single Lego compatible one costs upwards 40 euros with shipping (and I needed at least three).

The interroll company does not intend these to be driven, but they nicely provide CAD data, so I opened Fusion 360, and after a short work, I came up with this axle.

This first version needs still a bit of work, as the bush is still a bit too tight. Still, it fits, and I have a lot of torque transferred to wheels.

description.text:
I found myself needing something to magnify a circuit board when soldering SMC's. I found a guide on how to use a Pi camera to use it as a magnification device . From this guys is what you see now. I will like then guide as he deserves the credit for thinking up this . All I did is make a mount and I changed the type of camera used. This is the Camera I used. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JM94WCW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1. Also you will need a different cable to adapt to the Pi zero. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01M6XSBQC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1. The 2020 extrusions I used was from a failed print . They are about 95mm long. I would suggest that the base legs be 100 to 125mm long as with the cables hanging from the Pi it gets top heavy. I also added a small COB Led to the outer tab. It is a 12v led that I have running of a power supply. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00J23EA2U/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 . The guide I followed is very extensive and I did not go that deep as I didn't need the options that he had worked into his project. Here is the link to his project. https://www.instructables.com/id/Raspberry-Pi-Zero-HDMIWiFi-Soldering-Microscope/ .
As he has stated in this guide. As you get closer to your object the greater the magnification is going to be. This is why I went with a camera that the focus can be adjusted. The camera has a screw that locks the aperture down. Take the screw out and it will be difficult to get it to turn but once it breaks free it is easy to adjust.

This is a ring that can hold the top end of the diamond hotend heat sinks. I added 3x3.2mm holes through the part to add other mounting designs. All done in FreeCAD.

freecad blender fusion 360 cura

I had to look at some part drawings and measure a bit with calipers to get some dimensions. I want to thank the guy who posted the "official" diamond hotend mount. i tried to print that but it took a long time and sometimes the print would fail. so i redesigned my own. I am using a core xy Flying bear p902 with a horizontal carriage so i wanted to mount it underneath.

freecad can easliy open the "official" open scad files. the metal only one. but fusion cant. i wanted to try to print only the hotend mount without the blower, but no STL like that, so i took it into blender and deleted the blower lid, then after a few failed prints, decided to start from scratch and make my own.

24/06/17:after lot of try i make a models like an helix.this improvement reduce warping and have a better printability.i also add precision in print setting.

18/06/17:this is a test for pneumatic actuator might be useful for piston,suspension and muscle

description.text:
I needed a peg that I could attached to the verticals of a shelving unit. I use one as a spool holder, and another for a headphone hook.

You will need a large zip tie or strong string or twine to secure this to the shelf vertical. The shelving style this is designed for has tubular verticals that have indentations for helping shelves grip the verticals. Typically these wire shelves are seen in stores and commercial kitchens, but the hardware store by me carries them.

I don't know how strong they are, but I can say that v4 will print at low quality without supports, and be strong enough to hold a couple kilos. I enabled the customizer so that you can adjust the pole diameter if necessary, but I did not code in safeties. So don't put in any crazy dimensions.

I could have designed for bolts or for a fancy clip, but I think zip ties (or string) are a good reliable solution. I wanted this to be a single print, and easy to use. I had to have the back part because the v3 was just not holding onto the pole well.

Update 6-30-17: I have printed a V5 and I use it when I'm showing off to friends, but that v4 in the pictures is still working great.

UPDATE: Finally printed a V4. It has a print in place hinge and a back plate. This makes it hold onto the shelf much better. Don't bother with the v3 if you can print the v4.

I have a v5 that has a better hinge, but I don't see a need for it until I find a damning flaw with v4.

UPDATE: V4 is up, but I haven't test printed one yet.

UPDATE: added the V2 files because the single zip tie V3 is not holding as strong as I would like. Might make V4 with a variable zip tie height. I am trying to avoid screws or bolts.

TODO list:
-add an "I made this" entry so that Thingiverse sorts this as a printable object
-add a fillet/bevel to the bottom edges to give it a finished look.
-review the customizer options to make this more user friendly.

description.text:
This is a re-Mix of the Main Bearing Screw for the Fidget Spinner Press and bearing remover by mistertech, published Apr 26, 2017. This is a great tool, but I found the tool very hard to use for tight fitting bearings. My hands could not grip the round knob well enough to apply high torque.

As a solution I chose to add a T-Handle to the main screw, making it much easier to turn when high pressure was required.

I printed on a CEL-Robox printer at 1/10 scale using 90% fill factor and have been able to install bearings much easier.

Headphones holder - hanger for desk with 30 mm wide top. It slides 20 mm deep. I have sticked a few layers of masking tape on the bottom bit to make sure that it fits tightly but it doesn't damage the desk. There are 2 files headphone holder.stl - with 31 mm gap and headphone holder tight fit.stl - with 30.2 mm gap.

Dimensions:
Gap for table top - 31 mm / 30.2 mm in tight fit version
Width: 20mm
Maximum headset width: 40mm
Top part of the mount 5mm wide
Bottom part of the mount 4mm wide(so it'll fit between top and drawer)

http://shop.runcam.com/runcam-swift-mini/

A Chip-E inspired version, made with IOT esp8266 with micropython and pololu micro maestro.

Components:

  • pololu HD1160A x 4
  • Rechargeable battery x 1
  • 47 or more microfarad with 16v capacitor x 1
  • Voltage Regulator x 1
  • Pololu Micro Maestro x 1
  • mini esp8266 x 1

Video: https://youtu.be/YW0QO8uPXao

Pololu Programmer: https://youtu.be/EHDErrsMSlc

You can create your scripts very quickly in pythom, making it very versatile. The esp8266 provides 8 IO ports to customize your robot to the fullest. Now just let the imagination go free.

The pololu micro allows you to pre-program a sequence of steps on the PC and then execute them. A perfect match.

All the pieces were designed in openscad, can be customized at will. The design also supports a fundino board with arduino nano.

I used Tinkercad

author: Gophy

print_settings.Notes:: Note: To get correct thing-size, pleass scale it down to 10% before printing!

description.text:
This optimized water outflow nozzel was designed to improve water throughput of the Maytronics DOPLHIN Dynamic Plus pool cleaning robot. Especially cleaning steep walls, the robot has to provide good suction which directly depends on its flow rate.
I designed the part with Sketchup, sliced it with Simplify 3D and printed it with a German RepRap X400 Pro printer. I finally came to PLA (black colored due to better outdoor resistance compared to semi-transparent PLA) after four flops with ABS (warping).

Printer:

German RepRap X400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.22 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed with 1.75 mm PLA (Black) by German RepRap with a 0.4 mm Nozzle.
Nozzle temp was 193°C, heated bed temp was 58°C.
First layer speed reduction set to 20%. Default printing speed was set to 2000 mm/min. Layer thickness was set to 0.22 mm.
I used a brim (1 layer) with 15 turns.
Thin walls were prohibited to be filled with infill.
Three outline perimeter were used. Printing time was about 4 hrs (exclusive preheating machine).

Note: To get correct thing-size, pleass scale it down to 10% before printing!

Optimized water outflow nozzle for Maytronics pool robot DOLPHIN Dynamic Plus

In order to improve water thoughput of the robot for more efficient cleaning I re-designed the original part with a slightly longer tube with funnel shape. In opposition to the original part this new design encloses the propeller entirely. Due to the higher tightness between propeller and outflow an better flow guiding, an improved water throughput can be assumed.
First 5 testruns of the robot looked very promising.
Presumably this thing could fit also for other Maytronics pool robots.

Made with Trimble (Google) Sketchup

The part was fully designed by the help of Sketchup Pro 2017. Difficulties with the bended blades inside the funnel were solved by the very helpful plugin "Bezier Surface".

'Positive' of toolson's silicone damper to be printed in tpu.
Recommended settings see below.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30% and 40%

Notes:

Tpu 90A Shore, 30-40% infill with 0-1 perimeters.
Even 1 perimeter makes the area around the hole pretty stiff so try it without one if you want it even softer.
I like 30% cubic infill (slic3r prusa) with 0 perimeters the most.

comments.text: Tested and as i thought not good. Perimeters around the hole are too stiff.
comments.author: sobo84

comments.text: I tested it with 90A Shore with 40% (2 perimeters) and 60% (1 perimeter) Infill. Indeed it's very stiff especially at the hole. I will try 30% with 1 perimeter and report back. Maybe an even softer tpu might work (ninjaflex for example?).

description.text: Für die Änderung der Kabelführung am Druckkopf des RF100. Die kleine Zugentlastung ersetzt den originalen Metallwinkel. Die schrauben können wiederverwendet werden. Das zweite Objekt wird mit der Originalschraube und einer Unterlegscheide am Haltebügel des Druckkopfes angeschraubt. Hier passt auch die alte Schraube des Blechgehäuses. Bein anziehen der Schraube durch das Langloch den Winkel gegen den Haltebügel nach vorne schieben damit er sich dort winkelig abstützt. Zum Schluss noch das Flachbandkabel mit einem kleinen Kabelbinder durch die Löcher an der Zugentlastung befestigen.
NGSS

Dieser Drucker ist halt ein Billogerät um die Kundschaft für den 3D-Druck zu begeistern. Allerdings gefällt er mir vom Achsenkonzept her deutlich besser als seine großen Brüder RF1000 & RF2000.

Danke für die Fotos, nun ist es klar. Sehr nützlich.

author: ArnoNyme

description.text: Replacement for the cheap, fragile valence hanger extension bracket for our vertical blinds. Original was cast in clear plastic but, over time, the plastic became brittle and the clips broke that attached it to the horizontal rail. When designing the replacement I heavily reinforced the clips, printing with ABS allowed me to greatly increase the gripping power.
I printed the hanger with 100% fill and 1 shell which was probably overkill, interior fill could probably be reduced. Printing time was approximately 40 minutes.

This is an adapter for VPI record cleaners that allow it to hold down 7" 45 RPM records. It should cover the label of most 45s. After printing you might line the bottom with some foam for extra sealing and protection.

I printed this on a Replicator 2 with .2mm layer height, 2 shells, and 10% infill. It took about 51 minutes.  
The hole in the top should accommodate the threaded piece used to hold down 33 RPM records.  
I messed up the dimensions on the version in the pictures so it doesn't quite cover the label. The scad and STL files have the correct dimensions and will completely cover the label.

description.text:
Guardian Robot

This is an update to the Guardian Robot to provide room for electronics. I worked with Noe and lordtron to create useful hooks in this design.

Community

  • Sonoranguy Modified the feet to remove the rotating claws. The rotating claws can be flimsy which this would fix.
  • Pyrofer Check out this improved version of the guardian leg. It no long snaps in, but looks much closer to the original.
  • Noe designed a new base to secure a stepper motor and switch.
  • Blkhawk has updated Noe's base to work with more stepper motors and is working on a leg redesign. Also check out Blkhawk's updated details which allows him to print them separately.

Changes from original Guardian Robot

  • Removable base and head
  • Pass through in the base for cables from the legs
  • Room for a 10 mm LED in the head
  • Room for a small board and battery
  • Room for a servo motor, I've modeled a SG90
  • Mounting points for additional hardware in the body (see drawing)
  • Mounting points for a motor arm in the head (see drawing)
    • I modeled a servo arm for a SG90, but I recommend you model your own using the head mounting points.
    • A structure needs to be built for the motor securing it to the body.

Parts to Print

Hackable
  • body
  • base_cover
  • head
Details Separate

I've added files with the details separate to facilitate printing the hackable model with a dual extruder. The parts added are:

  • base_plain
  • base_cover
  • base_details
  • head_plain
  • head_details
  • hips_6
Details Separate, LED THRU

A modification recommended by Noe was to slice the details so that they penetrated to the interior of the body. This would allow a transparent material to be used which would allow an internal LED to shine through.

Update to Details Separate, LED THRU
I've modified the ears of the head to not use the secondary material. Printing these small details with a second material does not seem to work well.

  • base_plain_thru
  • base_cover
  • base_detail_thru_asm
  • head_plain_thru
  • head_details_thru_asm
  • hips_6

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

20

Notes:

Make sure your bed is level. This print has gaps of 0.3 - 0.5 mm between the moving parts.

comments.text: You have two options.  Either the original details separate which essentially slices the details off the face of the body or details through which is a normal cut through the details so that an LED in the interior can shine through.  The lists below detail the parts required for each build.  I've not built these models myself, but I've been shipped the model with the Details Thru and it turned out great.

title: Plot Function library for OpenSCAD, with Cartesian, Polar, and Axial coordinates

description.text:
This is a general purpose function plotting library for OpenSCAD which will render functions with Cartesian coordinates (x & y input, z output), polar/cylindrical coordinates (r & angle input, z output), or axial coordinates (z & angle input, r output). This library is sufficiently flexible that it can be used for more than just plotting functions. As demonstrated in the included demo files, this can efficiently render ordinary objects with surfaces defined by mathematical functions.

While there are a few other function plotting libraries out there for OpenSCAD, this one is particularly robust, fast, and flexible. It uses list comprehension to generate each plot as a single polyhedron, supports multiple user-defined functions of each type in one design, consistently creates properly manifold renders, and executes as quickly as any other rendered object of comparable size.

Since OpenSCAD does not support passing functions as parameters, this library resolves it by allowing the user to declare functions Func1, Func2, etc, PolarFunc1, PolarFunc2, etc, and AxialFunc1, AxialFunc2, etc. Then the number 1, 2, etc is passed to the corresponding plot routine. For example, the following code will create a Cartesian coordinate plot of the following function #1 over the domain -40 through 40 in both x and y with a step size of 0.4:

include <plot_function.scad>
function Func1(x, y) = 2*(1.5 + cos(x*x + y*y/4));
PlotFunction(1, [-40, 0.4, 40], [-40, 0.4, 40]);

The module call PlotFunction can occur anywhere a normal polyhedron could be generated, but the function definition Func1 must be declared at the top-level of the code so that it can be accessed from within the included plotting library. Note that it must "include" plot_function.scad rather than "use" it so that Func1 and others are accessible. A variety of usage demonstrations are in the demo_plot_function.scad file, and the API for the three plotting modules is as follows:

// Plots the numbered function Func1 through Func9, where FuncN is 1 through 9.
// Each function is a function of x and y.
// minx_stepx_maxx should be [minx, stepx, maxx], and likewise for y,
// specifying the domain to be plotted.
// To guarantee a properly manifold shape, the routine will only render
// strictly positive values (z>0) of the defined function.  Add an offset if
// needed to achieve this.
module PlotFunction(FuncN, minx_stepx_maxx, miny_stepy_maxy)

// Plots the numbered function PolarFunc1 through PolarFunc9, where
// PolarFuncN is 1 through 9.  Each function is a function of radius and
// angle.
// max_r is the outer radius, and min_step is the smallest step size between
// points.
// To guarantee a properly manifold shape, the routine will only render
// strictly positive values (z>0) of the defined function.  Add an offset if
// needed to achieve this.
module PlotPolarFunction(PolarFuncN, max_r, min_step=-1)

// Plots the numbered function AxialFunc1 through AxialFunc9, where
// AxialFuncN is 1 through 9.  Each function is a function of z-height and
// angle, and returns the radius outward in the xy-plane.
// max_r is the outer radius, and min_step is the smallest step size between
// points.
// minz_stepz_maxz should be [minz, stepz, maxz], and likewise for y,
// specifying the domain to be plotted.
// To guarantee a properly manifold shape, the routine will only render
// strictly positive values (r>0) of the defined function.  Add an offset if
// needed to achieve this.
module PlotAxialFunction(AxialFuncN, minz_stepz_maxz, num_circle_steps=360)

How it works internally

This section does not need to be read or understood to use the library. The key step in the design relies on the PlotClosePoints module which generates an arbitrary polyhedron given a two-dimensional array of points defining a series of consecutive loops outlining the polyhedron. This provides clear guarantees of producing a manifold shape as long as the outlining points are kept properly ordered by the Plot modules. The axial plots are then defined by loops from z=0 to the max height, with the radial distance outward of each point given by the provided function. The Cartesian plots are done similarly, but starting from the minimum y value, including 2 coordinate values for the bottom corners at the x max and x min, and looping across the x values. The polar plots start with the bottom outer ring and loop inward with consecutive rings for each radial value of the polar part, with the loops adopting whatever z value the provided function gives.

author: SchrodingersCat

title: Air Conditioner Run Cap Capacitor Holder

description.text:
Well, the Run Capacitor on my Air conditioning unit crapped out, and of course the replacement was a different diameter than the old one, and of course they don't just supply a clamp along with it any more.

They had a tie wrap holder, but the blasted little plastic holder cost more than the Run Cap. Umm, nah.

Figuring that I've got some other projects in the queue, where I need to strap down a capacitor, I thought I would just design one.

It's designed for a cap that is 55mm in diameter (I made it 57mm) and it is 90mm long.

It uses two #8 sheet metal screws to hold it in place, and I provided recesses for both the screw head (so it doesn't touch the cap), and a small recess on the back, so when you tighten up the screw and the metal deforms a bit, it has someplace to go.

Just slip the 3 tie wraps in before you mount it.

This would be fine for the audio buffs, who put monster caps in their cars for their massive sub-woofers.

If you need it for a larger capacitor, just message me the diameter and length of the cap, and I'll knock one out for you.

Enjoy.

description.text:
A modern slightly futuristic lamp.

I wanted to make something awesome for the hallway that fitted in a modern interior. The lamp had to be printable on a 20 x 20 cm (7,87 ") build plate, therefore I chose a snap together design. For the electronic part I chose a cheap IKEA fitting, but this could have also been from another brand.

remixed_from.author: AndrewBCN
remixed_from.title: Parametric Filament Spool Hub with 608ZZ bearing

description.text:
Here is my spool holder for 52mm centred spools and an 8mm shaft.
The openscad files can be edited to change the sizes.

The spool hub uses a printed in place planetary bearing.
There is a choice between a collar that requires a 3mm nut and bolt or a screw together collar with a tapered thread using the threads library by Dan Kirshner.

No need for metal bearings and the planetary gears give a little resistance so the spool does not run on and release too much filament and prevents tangles.
Both collars interlock with the centre of the bearing to prevent the bearing spinning on the rod. Its a good idea to restrain the rod to prevent that turning as well.
Then the spool will only turn on the planetary gears providing some resistance to prevent the spool from running on.

Obviously inspired by Emmett's gear bearing and AndrewBCN's spool hub.
And the threads library by Dan Kirshner. See file for details and licence.

19 June 2017: Added MiddleScrewCollar.stl and modifies ScrewCollar.scad to generate it.
This adds a centre piece that can lock into another spool holder to act as a locking collar between two spools. So it has the keyway on both ends. Needs printing with support.

21 June 2017: Marked as work in progress since it needs a bit more tweeking.
The helical gears are binding a bit. I need to work out best parameters.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm nozzle, 0.2mm layers

Infill:

varies

Notes:

100% infill for screw collar.
40% for other parts.
First layer do not increase flow or width of first layer.

Printed in ABS on kapton tape.
Nozzle 250, Bed 95.

A 0.4mm nozzle may be able to print all of these parts with clearance for the gears but I tend to use a 0.3mm nozzle on my hexagon all metal.

I used a brim on the screw collar as very little is in contact with the bed.
Use support for MiddleScrewCollar.stl due to the keyway on the bottom.
Probably best to print MiddleScrewCollar.stl on its own as support is not needed for the other parts.

The gear has a slight fillet on the bottom side against the bed to prevent spread or elephants foot. Try and print with a 100% bottom layer or you will have to carefully pick out all of the plastic spread out joining the gears.

Post printing

Remove any brim.

Carefully screw the collar together.
You may need to sand/file the ends of the inner and outer threads a little to ease fit.
It has a tapered thread that is easy to cross thread.

The other collar requires a 3mm nut pushed into the trap and a suitable 3mm bolt.

The geared spool hub needs to be carefully eased to break out the gears.
If yours cant be broken out you may need to adjust your print settings or change the clearance in the openscad file.
I used an 8mm nut and bolt through the centre hole and tightened till it grips and turned it with a spanner.

OpenScad

Designed in openscad

description.text:
I could not find a pi 3 case that fit my needs. So this is what I made. (Should also fit a Pi 2)

Some of the features I included are:

  • Slots above the display and camera headers for the cables.
  • Indentation inside the lid to make a cutout should the gpio be needed.
  • Cutout for the SD card to aid in removal being the 3b does not have a push to release.
  • Mounting location on the lid for a 30mm fan.
  • Recess in base to accommodate a low profile heat sink on the lower chip. (Set I used can be found here: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01GM9EYQ8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 )

I am open to suggestions for improvements to this design. I welcome all feedback.
My tolerances are very tight on this. In fact, I can snap the lid to the base and it will stay without screws. Your mileage may very.

Screw holes are made to accept a #4 sheet metal screw. I used #4 x 3/4 stainless screws found at my local orange big box store. (1/2 in would be fine too. Also m3 possibly.)

I have also included 2 STL TEST files that will allow you to print a hacked up version of the 2 parts to check for fit before you print the whole thing. This is up to you whether or not you do it. They are smaller, use less time and filament, and will give you an idea if it will work for you before the big print.

Hope this case is useful to you.

And as always, Print On! -- The Fun King

Doing the beveled edge for the ring was a snap for OpenSCAD. Basic cylinder with base 2mm larger that the top of the object. Getting the beveled edge on the hinge backing, not so much. Figuring out the dimensions of the cube needed, then 'unwrapping' the cube into flat faces and reassembling programmatically was a challenge. Then figuring out the hole pattern for the 3 original mounting holes was another challenge. Fortunately, the holes are in an equilateral triangle formation, so having 1 hole on the X axis made the other two easier to locate using a triangle as a guide.

description.text: motor shield

Make your own aero props

Step 1. Heat up water to about 65°C (150°F)
Step 2. Insert bamboo skewer into flat aero prop
Step 3. Insert aero prop in between two molds
Step 4. Heat up each side of the mold in the water
Step 5. Close mold completely and submerge in hot water for a few seconds
Step 6. Open mold and remove curved aero prop
Step 7. Use the top mold as a guide to cut off bamboo screwer at the right length
Step 8. Have fun

author: Jelmer95

description.text:
This guard fits Wahl brand clippers sold at Costco. This guard is slightly closer than a #1. I like to call it a #1/2 but i do not actually know. I printed this in grey hatchbox pla.

Printing:
I printed it on it's small edge to maintain strength where the clippers need it the most. My printer also likes to steal ~0.5mm in the z due to the heated glass bed so printing it on the side kept the blades from being weakened.

I printed it at ~50mm/s, 0.1 layer size, 15% infill, 15% support and 1.2mm walls.

Printing on edge requires support.

Design:
I did the fit of the clippers face first. I then drew a master blade in the plane of the guard edge to meet my length requirements and to fit the clippers. This was a connected poly-line that I extruded to form my first blade right on the edge of the clippers. I multiplied and transformed the blade across the tip of the guard and added support to the blades on the end for extra strength and to hold the clippers better. I then filleted the sharp edges to make it a bit nicer on the scalp.

description.text: An extension for a faucet to allow young kids to reach the water stream.

Print in your material of choice.  PLA might eventually degrade, but hopefully not before your kid grows a little taller.  Seal with polyurethane or acrylic if you like, and fasten to the faucet with a zip tie or rubber band.  No 3D printed material is approved for use with potable water, so this is for washing hands.  
Note that this design was made for a faucet that angles upward.   It'll work on flatter faucets, but won't reach as far.

description.text:
No Nuts Front Support Struts for the Anet A8.

Frightened to touch your display while printing for fear of lifting your head 3mm off the print? Me too! and I've been meaning to do something about the instability of the front of the A8 for a while and photoberto posted a great solution here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2351450.

I've modified it so that it takes up a little less space and does not require any nuts as the 6mm bar threads into the print itself.

I've also opened up the threads a little on the files posted here as the threaded bar needed some persuading to get it into the holes on my first attempt. I've also removed some gaps.

title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8 - Beefed up Y motor mount for 2020 extrusion

description.text:
I started printing the parts for the "AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8" after my acrylic frame became toast... FYI - Don't use thread lock on your screws.

I liked the idea in this variant of the frame: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:348441 which uses 2 X 2020 extrusions for the bed, this lowers the bed and gives you an additional 20mm of Z travel. But this made the motor mount too tall, and left only one hole for attaching the mount to the frame, so I made a wider one with more holes for 2020. There is two versions, one with channel support and one without. Printing the support can be challenging, and probably isn't that necessary.

I am still waiting on parts to finish the build, the mount should work, but use at your own risk until Ive tested it out.

comments.text:
Hey, this looks great! I also saw the 2020 variant you mentioned in your description and want to do the same as well. The Y motor was something I was concerned about in using the smaller 2020 extrusion for those 2 pieces.
Have you had a chance to test this yet? If so I'd love to see some pics!
comments.author: JZE

comments.text: I haven't got all the supplies yet, but I think if I had to do it again I would have just stuck with the 2040s. Especially since I already am switching to 500mm height on the machine. I didnt take into consideration any Y chains I may install, its going to be hard to bend to 20mm.
comments.author: JZE

comments.text:
Ahh bummer haha I actually just ordered the extrusions and I went with the 2020 for the front and back. I also ordered 500mm uprights to increase the Z height, and longer extrusions for the left/right and front/back so I can upgrade to like a 300x300 print bed if I decide to.
But thanks for the reply! Hopefully it'll still work out alright with the 2020 pieces. Even if we might not be able to use a Y chain.
I'd love to see you printer when you get this mod all finished!

comments.text: I gave up on the 2020 extrusion idea. I had issues on the Z motors no being able to get the X carriage down to the bed, so I gave up. 20 mm wasn't that much of an improvement when I already have 100+ more MM after I added longer screws and rods.

description.text:
What it is

A stand for the nintendo switch. Printed in 3 parts for 2 reasons. First, there is no good orientation to print that as one part. Second, it can break down into a small package to take on the go.

Why do I need this

  1. The built in kickstand on the nintendo switch is terribly flimsy.
  2. The built in kickstand on the nintendo switch is off to one side and does not offer great stability
  3. The built in kickstand on the nintendo switch does not provide access to the usb-c charging/display port when in use.
  4. Cause it is awesome.

Will you print it for me?

If you ask nicely.

Please and Thank Yous

Feel free to enjoy and modify. If you do happen to make any improvements, please let me know so I can incorporate.

Happy remixing

Notes

This was my first ABS print. I did not have excellent setting for the printing of all of the parts. You will probably notice some delamination on the cross bar. I will reprint this some day and post new photos. But for now, I will deal with it. :D

You can see some delamination in the last photo on the crossbar. I've since tweaked my settings and my ABS prints have been much better. I will reprint this one day.

title: Life Size Han Solo Blaster (Vintage Kenner Star Wars Action Figure Inspired)

description.text:
This prop is based on the weapon that came with the vintage Kenner Star Wars Han Solo figure, although it's not really meant to be an exact recreation. I've included three different versions: the full model, the full model split up into 7 parts that can be glued together to minimize support material and make it possible print a life-size blaster on smaller printers, and a small keychain model with a hole in the handle.

The two models that aren't in pieces are oriented to be upside-down on the print bed, but you might find that printing with the barrel facing upward gives better results (however, this may limit the size of the gun depending on your printer). You will probably still want to leave supports on even if you print the model in pieces, since there are a few places that can benefit from a little support. The majority of the blaster is just fine using .3m layer height, but the scope parts look better at lower layer heights because of their curves.

In the photos you can see the keychain, the model printed in parts and assembled, and the model finished with techniques like gap filling, sanding, priming and painting for a smoother look.

I have marked this model as non-commercial because I don't want people just selling it on eBay or Etsy, but I have no problem with people printing it for friends or things like that. If you print this, PLEASE post a make! Thanks!

description.text:
I wanted to create telescope of high light power and low magnification. This set of model is what I created for the project. I printed it with ABS plastic, so some parts models have alternatives that greatly simpify ABS print dealing with warping difficulties. Some parts have alternatives with embedded support to just imprive end result vs. slicer generated support.
All parts use 1mm pitch thread with 60 degree form of teeth.
I got 110 mm x2 magnification lens in my local optics store. Its actual focal length is 270-280mm, while it should be 250mm (4 dioptre).
www.connevans.co.uk/product/4835381/MX700040/Handheld-Illuminated-Magnifier--110mm-Lens--2x-Magnification
www.amazon.co.uk/d/Magnifying-Glasses/Handheld-Illuminated-Magnifier-110mm-Magnification/B00P9E02G4
www.ebay.co.uk/p/handheld-illuminated-magnifier-110mm-lens-2-x-magnification/2038601768

Unfortunately I did not find lenses with less magnification number (longer focal length) to create telescope of higher image quality.
You can use 1.25''/2'' eyepieces with the scope depending on eyepiece holder you use.

I modeled helicoidal focuser with photo lens similar control. It has 32mm range of focusing, with 10mm position for infinity, so eyepieces with shifted parfocality can be used as well. Since 2'' eyepieces have more deep placement of focal plane the 2'' eyepiece holder accounts this in the model.

The scope is ready to be printed and tested.
Use standard 50/70mm dovetail model with 1/4'' thread (1/20'' pitch) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2402072
(thread is standard for photo tripod) for telescope holder tripods. If you already have telescope dovetail you can use it securing it on body brace.
Also blend and lens cover can be added.

Note: do not expect exceptional quality from this telescope since contemporary refractor telescopes have achromatic corrective lens (flint glass) in addition to main crown glass that significantly reduces spherical and chromatic abberations. This scope is limited to 10mm minimum eyepiece use and thus x27-28 usable magnification. Higher magnifications (lower eyepiece focal length) do not give clear view due to spherical and chromatic abberations (polyethylene-like view). So respect $100 telescopes that have flint glass and may give x100 and higher magnification.

UPD

  • 06/27/2017 - 0A-eyepiece_holder_2_inch is increased by 0.2mm in internal diameter (after probe print in ABS and test with my old good 2'' eyepiece). New version shall hold 2 inch eyepiece tightly, while previous version did not fit the eyepiece a bit.

Printer:

JGAURORA Z - 605S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Layer 0.1 mm Nozzle 0.4 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

0.1 mm layer resolution is recommended since most part have thread. Use of sup versions of models is recommended, since it improves result without use of slicer generated support. _sup_04 is for 0.4mm nozze, while _sup_05 is for 0.5mm nozzle.
04-focuser tube has most difficulty with ABS due to warping and uneven cooling of the model. So sup is must for the model, while model without *sup is just for reference only to have idea how end result shall look.
05-focusing ring has embedded support inside helicoid groove, that shall be carefully removed after print. Spend half an hour to clean it for smooth eyepiece tube movement.
03-body and 06-eyepiece tube shall be printed with slicer generated support to properly print brace and helicoid boss.

Focuser pieces have 0.2mm gap along radius between them, so working surfaces have to be processed with sand-paper after print for more smooth movement.

Clean all parts from brim, sand-paper focuser parts for smooth movement of parts. Use acetone for focuser if it is printed with ABS, and you wish some gloss from ABS.
Assemble parts in the order they numbered. When everything printed well you may glue 03 and 06 parts to prevent their movement during focuser use.

description.text:
This is a spool hook with axe 6mm.
The axe needs to be centered by 2 small spacers.
The spool hole is 31mm large.

print_settings.Notes:: You may find it useful to try to minimize the material used in these pieces, both because they're so large, and because it's a big hunk of plastic on the end of a staff that you'll be waving around. I personally used Cura to print with 0.2mm layer height, 2 walls, 3 top layers, 3 bottom layers, and 50% Grid infill with 3 gradual infill steps of 1mm each (so most of it is printed in ~6.25% infill, and only the top bits get more infill so that the surface gets printed flat). This got me down to about 1 pound for the entire head piece. Again, this is totally optional; it should be a very easy piece to print so at this point it becomes a game of optimizing for whatever you care about.

title: Mikleo staff from Tales of Zestiria
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a model for the head and tail of Mikleo's staff from Tales of Zestiria.

The pieces are modelled to fit onto a Schedule 40 PVC pipe with 1/2" ID / 0.84" OD, which can be picked up at your local hardware store for about $2-3. It should be very easy to change this in the Solvespace file if you need to, though you probably can't make it much bigger without increasing the thickness of the staff head/tail to compensate.

This includes STLs for the whole pieces, but also split STLs that are intended to be printable far more easily / without supports / in an 8"x8" printer.

To make the head, just print 2 of each head piece and assemble them however you like (glue + woodfill is good). For the tail, just 2 of the tail piece.

Credit for the 2D sketches (the contours extruded to make the final STL), as well as the subject of the example photo and construction of the physical prop, goes to @Helios748 (https://twitter.com/helios748/). Photo credit: @Otattemita.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

Ordinary PLA should be fine. I do recommend a brim for these if you're having adhesion issues on the pointy bits. If you're using the separate pieces and not cutting it up yourself, I highly recommend printing with the cylindrical hole facing down.

You may find it useful to try to minimize the material used in these pieces, both because they're so large, and because it's a big hunk of plastic on the end of a staff that you'll be waving around. I personally used Cura to print with 0.2mm layer height, 2 walls, 3 top layers, 3 bottom layers, and 50% Grid infill with 3 gradual infill steps of 1mm each (so most of it is printed in ~6.25% infill, and only the top bits get more infill so that the surface gets printed flat). This got me down to about 1 pound for the entire head piece. Again, this is totally optional; it should be a very easy piece to print so at this point it becomes a game of optimizing for whatever you care about.

description.text:
27/10/17/ X Carriage updated

Premièrement merci @Neo_Usagi pour son travail sur le souffleur avec aimant -> https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1165614/#files
et @NeilLX pour son travail sur le châssis extrudeur -> https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1808378

J'ai retravaillé le châssis X original pour le rendre plus léger, adapté un tendeur de courroie, créé une pièce pour fixer le Bltouch et finalement dessiné une dernière pièce afin de mettre un ventilateur de 40mm pour le refroidisseur du hotend (celui d'origine est bien trop bruyant).

Les dessins ne sont pas parfaits j'ai du faire quelques adaptations et vu le temps que j'ai passé dessus je préfère les donner dans la description pour que vous les appliquiez, je mettrais à jour les STL plus tard.

Support Bltouch: Il faudra surement légèrement découper au cutter la partie qui rentre dans le support de roulement, rien de grave. J'ai du rajouter 1 écrou intermédiaire pour voir une hauteur convenable.

Hotend: Le souffleur du hotend a été imprimé en ABS et collé à l'acétone au support ventilateur 30mm de Neo_Usagi. Pour que le souffleur soit bien étanche j'ai fait de jus d'ABS très épais pour combler tout ça.

I worked again the frame X original to make it lighter, adapted a belt holder, created one part to fix Bltouch and finally drawn a last part to put a 40mm fan for hotend (the original is too noisy).

Drawings are not perfected I have of to make some adaptations and seen the time which I spent I prefer to give them in the description so that you applied them, I'll update the STL later.

Bltouch support: it will be necessary to cut certainly the part which goes into the bearing housing, nothing serious. I have of to add 1 intermediate nut to see a suitable height.

Hotend: The hotend blower was printed in ABS and stick with the acetone with the Neo_Usagi hotend 30mm fan stl. I made juice of ABS to fill all this and make it sealed.

description.text:
There sure are a bunch of SD card holders out there, and now there's one more. Yay.

Why another? Well, it seems like most folks have a whole bunch less SD cards than I do, especially those damned micro SD converters. I think those things are getting together when I'm not looking and making more of themselves.

Either way, I don't need fancy storage with a slot for each card, although for the micros, that does make a bit of sense.

Listed ajb79's modular memory holder as a source as I took measurements from it to save myself that work, but then it's all modeled from scratch in SketchUp. (I really need to take the time to learn some proper CAD, but I know this well enough for now) Plus, ajb79's design is pretty clever with the modular snap-together design, so a little publicity isn't a bad thing.

It's not fancy, it's not pretty, but it'll hold a bunch of SD cards in no particular order. Hope it helps someone.

description.text:
This are height adjustable stand offs for my cheap chinese k40 laser machine. They are designed to be hotglued on the floor of the machinebed for the cutting surface to be placed on. the grip ring is to fix the M8 sleeve nut on the M8x55mm bolt. I get around 10 to 15mm difference in height with this setup.

NOTE: The cutting surface gets just laid on the stand off. next step is to design a system that allows some sort of fixation of the cutting surface.

NOTE: Print height_adjustment_1 on its head to minimize unsupported overhangs.
generally scale the parts to compensate shrinkage as the tolerances are very tight. 3% gave me the best result for a snug fit.

A 45 degree connector for 40mm x 40mm extrusion, 8020inc's 4040 lite. I am using it as a corner brace on a large format 3d printer frame. These are much easier to print than the 1 piece 90 degree corner that I made

description.text:
Started with 2ROBOTGUY's Tri Fidget Spinner Toy, but instead of using three more bearing sets for the weights (which are expensive, right?), I used some 5/8" ball bearings I had left over from the castors of a robot. They add a lot of mass, and will rotated in the housing giving another "fidget" activity along with spinning.

You need to heat the body with a hair drier or hot air gun and press the ball in (not too hot, or it will warp).

I also designed the finger pads from scratch. I've tried a couple and of nothing worked the way I wanted.

author: SwissGravityForce

description.text:
I wanted to make a modular tower that I could print and possibly re-arrange later if the need arose. I could probably (and may eventually) do other polygons, but for now I have a 12-Sided tower that can be built as high as you're willing to print parts. The pieces will stand on their own stacked, but I plan on gluing together sets of four to make each floor. I don't think they'd be stable enough for play on their own.

I will eventually make bridges so you can place them across doorways at higher levels. I may work on a working door piece too.... this kinda fell together over the weekend... so I have pictured what I've printed so far.

Suggestions are welcome, I think I've just scratched the surface of what I could potentially do with this. There is almost no need for supports on these parts. I tried to keep that in mind as I made these. The archway in the door is the only part I printed with supports.

EDIT: 6/19/17 - Added hollow stair version with offset window.

EDIT: 6/25/17 - Added 5 new building sections, double open and closed doors, windows, etc.

This is a door handle bumper that slips over either a 19mm or 16mm door handle. The unused hole and middle part will protect the wall or other door from impact from the door handle.

This particular design is mine, but it is loosely based on a similar bumper that has been used in my home for more than 30 years. This is a bike stem mount for owners of the FRiEQ iPhone 7 armband case (available for ~$10 as of this writing) and the stock stem on a circa 2014 Canondale Synapse (though many other stems can likely be used with minor adaptation). The FRiEQ system consists of an always-on case and precisely-fitting outer shell into which the phone slides. If you're a user of the armband system, having a similarly secure mount on your bike is great!

This one consists of two pieces: an insert for the FRiEQ shell and a base mount for the bike stem. The two are joined using m3 machine screws with captive hex nuts.

Why not create a replacement for the portion manufactured by FRiEQ? Well, you could. Its tolerances are quite precise, though, and it would have taken a considerable amount of work to quantify and replicate. For the price, I decided that buying another FRiEQ was simpler, but I welcome contributions from anyone who wants to make this project completely printable.

Recommendations for your build:

  • Use a soldering iron to coax the m3 nuts into position with heat. The model is not designed to fit them without heat to get them in place.
  • I recommend placing a section of bicycle innertube between the stem and base mount to prevent sliding.
  • I affixed the base mount with zip ties. A hose clamp will work fine too, but is heavier.
  • Be careful not to use much force when inserting the screws: if misthreaded into the nuts you can easily snap off the supporting plastic arms of the base. If it's resisting, back it out, apply some sideways pressure to get a different angle on the screw, and try again.
  • The base mount is designed for the somewhat idiosyncratic flanging of my Canondale Synapse stem. I suspect that some padding, innertube rubber or modifications in Sketchup could make it fit your bike nicely, too. It might even work as-is!

This system appears quite secure, but I have not put enough miles on it to be 100% certain that the PLA will stand up to ultraviolet light, that vibration won't damage the mount, or that anything else won't go wrong. Use at your own risk.
